title: Bistricë (river)
text:
Bistricë (definite: Bistrica) is a river in southwestern <a href="Albania">Albania</a>. It ends in the <a href="Ionian%20Sea">Ionian Sea</a>. Name of the river is of the Slavic origin, meaning "clear (water)".
Geography.
Bistricë starts from <a href="Mali%20i%20Gjer%C3%AB">Mali i Gjerë</a> (also known as "Sopot") in <a href="Finiq">Finiq</a> municipality directing initially versus south-west. The main source is near <a href="Krongj">Krongj</a> (<a href="Blue%20Eye%2C%20Albania">"The Blue Eye" source</a>), also gathering other sources from the nearby villages of Pecë, Kardhikaq, Velahovë, and other smaller brooks. It passes through <a href="Mesopotam">Mesopotam</a> and <a href="Finiq">Finiq</a> municipalities, parallel with the <a href="Sarand%C3%AB">Sarandë</a>-<a href="Gjirokast%C3%ABr">Gjirokastër</a> road.
Initially the river ended in <a href="Lake%20Butrint">Lake Butrint</a>, which connects with the Ionian sea through the <a href="Vivar%20channel">Vivar channel</a>. In 1958, it was deviated to <a href="%C3%87uk%C3%AB">Çukë</a> channel.
The river is 25 km long.
Economy and tourism.
The river is not navigable. There is an <a href="artificial%20lake">artificial lake</a> with the same name () built on its basin, and three <a href="Hydroelectricity">hydro-power stations</a> built in the '60. The river's waters are used to a certain extent as a supply for the nearby fields of <a href="Vurg">Vurg</a> area. All the stations passed through the privatization process from 2010 with plenty of controversies.
<br>A well known touristic place is the "<a href="Blue%20Eye%2C%20Albania">Azure Eye</a>", often referred as "Blue Eye" (), a spring tributary to Bistrica river near the village named Krongj, with a rich flora and fauna.
